packagegui.name: netsnmp_users
packagegui.title: NET-SNMP

field.description: SNMPv3 user entries define accounts that can query this SNMP agent. Entries can be for username and password authentication (USM), certificate-based authentication (TSM), or both.

The type of entry described by these settings.
In a User Entry, only the SNMPv3 USM User Configuration and Access Control sections will be used. With a Certificate Mapping entry, only the Certificate Mapping section will be used.

option.name: Both User Entry and Certificate Mapping

field.description: Select the type of access this user will have.
Restrict the user to part of the tree rooted at this OID. Leave blank to allow full access.

SNMPv3 USM user configuration is relatively easy for clients to use. The parameters can be supplied on the command line or stored in ~/.snmp/snmp.conf
To utilize user authentication at the command line, which is not secure, supply all of the parameters: 
snmpget -v 3 -l authPriv -a SHA -A 1234567890 -u myuser -x AES -X 1234567890 localhost nsExtendOutputFull.\"ls\"
To define the parameters more securely, create a file in ~/.snmp/snmp.conf with permissions such that it can only be read by the user (e.g. 0600), with the following contents: 
defSecurityName myuser
defSecurityLevel authPriv
defAuthType SHA
defAuthPassphrase mypassword
defdefPrivType AES
defPrivPassphrase mypassphrase
defVersion 3
The authentication algorithm to use. SHA is more secure, but may not be supported by all clients.
Enter the password here. Must be 8 characters or longer.
The privacy protocol (encryption) to use. AES is more secure, but may not be supported by all clients.
Enter the privacy passphrase to use with the privacy protocol. Optional. If left blank, the password will be used. Must be at least 8 characters.
The minimum security level allowed for this user when connecting via USM.

SNMPv3 Certificate Mapping entries define a relationship between client certificates and SNMP users.
These entries do not define general characteristics, but specific mappings. The field paramter tells snmpd what part of the certificate contains the username to match.

Create a Certificate Authority, a Server Certificate, and User Certificates before configuring certificate mappings.

Export the CA certificate, Server Certificate, User Certificate, and the User Certificate Key and copy them to the client. On UNIX and similar systems, these files should be placed in ~/.snmp/tls/ in the following structure: 
~/.snmp/tls/ca-certs/ca.crt
~/.snmp/tls/certs/snmpd.crt
~/.snmp/tls/certs/myuser.crt
~/.snmp/tls/private/myuser.key
To use the certificates when connecting to the server, pass the appropriate names to an SNMP command such as snmpget. 
snmpget -v 3 -t 10 --defSecurityModel=tsm --defSecurityName=myuser \
	--defSecurityLevel=authPriv --localCert=myuser --peerCert=snmpd --trustCert=ca \
	tls:server.example.com:10161 sysContact.0
These parameters can also be defined in ~/.snmp/snmp.conf or in a host-specific configuration file such as ~/.snmp/hosts/server.conf 
defVersion 3
defSecurityModel tsm
defSecurityName myuser
defSecurityLevel authPriv
localCert myuser
peerCert snmpd
trustCert ca
A numerical priority for matching this mapping.

The SSL User Certficate for use with DTLS.
Choose "None" if DTLS will not be used. (Default: none)
The field of the certificate to use when mapping a username.
The name to use when Manual Security Name is chosen above.
The minimum security level allowed for this user when connecting via TSM.
